title: Hi, I’m Gary!
text:
I’m a freelance analytics lead and product manager with 10 years of experience.
This is the corner of the internet where I share my thoughts, my projects and what I learn.
You can read more about me and the services I offer below.
I am currently available for work and based in Berlin, Germany.







C’est moi

title: Hi, I’m Gary!
text:
About me
I combine hands-on know-how and leadership experience in analytics and product development. In other words, I’m an analyst with product development experience or a product manager with strong analytical skills.
I can lead projects or teams to deliver work that moves the needle. I can also directly contribute thanks to years of experience as a product analyst:

find patterns and insights in millions of records of customer behaviour data,
prepare and visualise data using SQL, R or Python,
launch, monitor and analyse a/b tests,
equip teams with KPIs, dashboards and curated datasets.

I am comfortable working as a bridge between business leaders and technical teams. I can translate business questions into data problems and data insights back into business decisions.
The bulk of my experience deals with extracting insights from quantitative data sources. Nonetheless, I also have experience with qualitative data. I have carried-out small scale user interviews and usability tests for products I managed as well as survey analyses.
I acquired this breadth of skills mostly during my 8-year tenure at Zalando (European e-commerce scale-up). I got to grow alongside a company that was scaling from startup energy to enterprise sophistication. Most notably, I was part of the first cohort of product analysts in the company. I had the chance to work in teams at different stages of the product development process, always building the customer-facing web and app experiences. I ended writing documents that establish best practices for analytics during product development, I participated in the creation of the group’s data strategy and I later guided others into growing into these roles as a team lead.
Finally, I feel very comfortable in international environments. I find it easier to work in English than in my native French. I am also at-ease working in multidisciplinary teams (designers, engineers, product managers, etc.)

Working with me
My approach is heavily influenced by Amazon’s working backwards model: start with what you’re trying to achieve, then figure out how to get there.
I bring a calm and organised approach to projects. I believe in finishing what we started first and in having transparent prioritisation mechanisms to keep things manageable. In addition, I approach ambiguity with serenity. Data combined with product management methods are great to reduce uncertainty and gain clarity.
I am open to feedback and I take it to heart to improve whenever given the chance.
I am used to cultures where we surface and discuss problems in an honest and dispassionate manner. I strive to leave my ego out of the equation and focus on what’s best for the company.
Experience has taught me to be realistic about what data can and cannot do. I focus on insights that can actually influence decisions. I prefer to work in iterations. Incremental improvements beat grand plans that never ship.
I’m comfortable working in large corporate environments and understand how to navigate complex organizational structures effectively. Whether it’s a fast-growing scale-up or a digital transformation initiative within a traditional company, I know how to work within existing processes while getting things done.


What I can do for you
Strategic leadership:

Product management for your data projects
Lead or principal product analyst roles
Help develop analytics practices within your product organisation
Accompany you in generating actionable insights from customer behaviour data

Hands-on support:

Exploratory data analysis and insight generation
KPI definition and reporting frameworks
A/B testing and experimentation programs
ETL, automation, and data pipeline work

While most of my experience comes from e-commerce, I’m interested in working with all types of online services, websites, and apps. Good analytics principles translate across industries.


Contact
Whether you’re looking for help with a specific project or just want to chat about analytics/product management, feel free to reach out via LinkedIn, Mastodon, or email.

title: Creating the favicon for this website with ggplot2
section: What kind of graphic am I trying to create?
text:
What kind of graphic am I trying to create?
I’m trying to re-create the favicon used for a previous iteration of my personal website:

Square shape
Solid blue background color
My initials “GT” positioned on top, towards the bottom of the square.

I’m starting simple. Should be doable, right?

title: Creating the favicon for this website with ggplot2
text:
Setup
Installing and loading ggplot2.

install.packages('ggplot2')
library("ggplot2")

Here, I set the default size of my plots for the rest of the document. It is an important setting since I will generate a square icon and, by default, dimensions are 7 x 5 inches.

knitr::opts_chunk$set(
  fig.width = 5,
  fig.height = 5
)

title: Creating the favicon for this website with ggplot2
text:
Creating the graphic
I decided to tackle the blue background first. I remembered that ggplot has different geoms to create a square. I looked up the documentation and started coding.
I iterated through geom_raster(), geom_rect() and landed on geom_tile(). It is best suited for my use case. I just need to define the size of the square and use the origin (0,0) as the center of the square.

square_size <- 5
my_blue <- "#0063dc"

(p <- ggplot() +
  geom_tile(
    aes(x = 0, y = 0, width = square_size, height = square_size),
    fill = my_blue
  ))








Now, I will 1) add the text, position it, and then 2) remove all plot elements like grid lines, axes, etc.

(p <- p +
  geom_text(
    aes(
      x = 0,
      y = -square_size / 5,
      label = "GT",
      family = "Inter",
      fontface = "bold"
    ),
    color = "white",
    size = square_size / 2,
    size.unit = 'in'
  ) +
  theme(rect = element_rect(fill = "transparent")) +
  theme_void()
)








Voilà!
On purpose, I defined the position of the text and its size as a factor of the variable square_size. I hope that it will make it easier to export this graphic in different sizes after.
Regarding the font, I’m using Inter. I had to download and install it on Mac OS for it to become available in the plot.

title: Creating the favicon for this website with ggplot2
section: Saving in various sizes and formats
text:
Saving in various sizes and formats
This is when things get more complicated for two reasons:

No clear spec for favicons exists. It depends on browsers, mobile OSes. Different formats, different sizes.
Resizing a plot is not as straightforward as I thought


Favicon specs
While browsing, I found various specs1 for this favicon. I will spare you the details. In the end, I landed on the following:

favicon.ico 32x32 (px)
favicon.png 96x96 (px)
apple-touch-icon.png 180x180 (px)
favicon.svg



Scaling issues
So far, I’ve set all my measurements in inches (figure size, font size). Now, my goal is to provide a size in pixels and to automatically resize and scale the icon accordingly.
The problem is…

ggsave(
  p,
  filename = "icons/favicon_problem.png",
  dpi = 'retina', #retina = 320, according to documentation
  width = 96,
  height = 96,
  units = 'px',
  bg = "transparent"
)


… that the dimensions are good, but the proportions are not. With ggsave I can easily define the size in pixels, but this doesn’t change the font size in the plot.
Christophe Nicault’s article Understanding text size and resolution in ggplot2 explains very well what happens. They recommend to use a package called ragg and the scaling option.
I tried, but simply installing ragg created a big error2 in Quarto and completely destroyed my ability to preview my post. I also played around with the scale option in ggsave(), to no avail.
As a result, I decided to handle the scaling myself.


DIY scaling
Since I’ve defined sizes in inches when creating the graphic and since I want to express icon dimensions in pixels, I need to understand the relationship between inches and pixels first.
From Understanding text size and resolution in ggplot2:

The relation is : (size in inches) = (screen size in pixel) / PPI or (screen size in pixel) = DPI * (size in inches)

In other words, if I want an icon with size 32 x 32 pixels, the conversion in inches will be 32 / 320 = 0.1 (with a resolution of 320). I can create a function that takes these two parameters as arguments, converts that to a measurement in inches and then passes that to ggplot2.

# Function that creates the icon with sizes in inches
create_icon <- function(square_size_inches) {
  p <- ggplot() +
    geom_tile(
      aes(
        x = 0,
        y = 0,
        width = square_size_inches,
        height = square_size_inches
      ),
      fill = my_blue
    ) +
    geom_text(
      aes(
        x = 0,
        y = -square_size_inches / 5,
        label = "G",
        family = "Inter",
        fontface = "bold"
      ),
      color = "white",
      size = square_size_inches /2,
      size.unit = 'in'
    ) +
    theme_void() +
    theme(
      plot.background = element_rect(fill="transparent", colour = NA),
      panel.background = element_rect(fill="transparent", colour = NA)
    )

    return(p)
  }

# Function that uses a size in pixels and a dpi to convert it into inches, create the icon and save it to disk
create_and_save_icon <- function(filename, size_pixels, dpi = 320) {
  square_size_inches <- size_pixels / dpi
  icon <- create_icon(square_size_inches)

  ggsave(
    plot = icon,
    filename = filename,
    dpi = dpi,
    width = size_pixels,
    height = size_pixels,
    units = 'px',
    bg = "transparent"
  )
}

Let’s try it out!

create_and_save_icon(filename = 'icons/favicon_32x32.png', size_pixels = 32, dpi = 320)


It works! I can now generate the different sizes that I need.

sizes = c(32, 96, 180)

for (size in sizes) {
  filename = paste0('icons/favicon_', size, 'x', size, '.png')

  create_and_save_icon(filename = filename, size_pixels = size, dpi = 320)
}







favicon_32x32.png







favicon_96x96.png







favicon_180x180.png





And for the last one, the .svg version. Here, we’ll use the base R built-in SVG graphics device:

icon <- create_icon(1)
svg("icons/favicon.svg", width = 1, height = 1)
print(icon)
invisible(dev.off())




favicon.svg
